importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The start date of the previous government shutdown, which began on December 22, 2018.
The end date of the previous government shutdown, which concluded on January 25, 2019, marking a 35-day duration—the longest in nearly 50 years.
The date the article was updated, indicating the current shutdown is ongoing as of this date.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time period during which the longest government shutdown in nearly 50 years occurred.
The current period during which a full government shutdown is ongoing due to lack of congressional appropriations.

keyTakeAways: The last government shutdown (2018–2019) lasted 35 days, the longest in nearly 50 years.
The shutdown cost the U.S. economy an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP according to the Congressional Budget Office.
During the 2018 shutdown, about 800,000 federal employees were affected, with approximately 300,000 furloughed and 300,000 exempted from pay but required to report to work.
The current shutdown (as of October 2025) is a full shutdown because Congress has not passed any of the 12 required appropriations bills.
Government shutdowns have become less common since 1990, but political partisanship and narrow majorities—such as Republican Speaker Mike Johnson’s—have made resolution difficult.
The 11th-hour negotiations in 2025 have stalled, with the GOP lacking 60 votes to overcome a Senate filibuster, making bipartisan compromise unlikely.
The U.S. federal government has not approved annual funding for most agencies, resulting in a halt of operations across multiple departments.

namedEntities.name: United States federal government
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The national government body whose operations are suspended during a shutdown.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The entity that is currently experiencing a full shutdown due to lack of funding.

namedEntities.name: Congress
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The legislative branch of the U.S. government responsible for passing appropriations bills.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Congress has failed to pass any of the 12 appropriations bills, leading to the current government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: House of Representatives
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The lower chamber of Congress, currently led by Speaker Mike Johnson.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Speaker Mike Johnson oversees one of the narrowest House majorities, contributing to political stalemate and stalled negotiations.

namedEntities.name: Senate
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The upper chamber of Congress, where a filibuster can block passage of legislation.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The GOP lacks the 60 votes needed to overcome a Senate filibuster, preventing passage of spending bills.

namedEntities.name: Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Republican Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He leads a narrow House majority, which makes bipartisan compromise difficult and contributes to the difficulty of ending the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Congressional Budget Office (CBO)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nonpartisan office that provides economic analyses, including estimates of economic impacts.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The CBO estimated that the 2018 shutdown cost the U.S. economy $3 billion in lost GDP.

namedEntities.name: 2018–2019 government shutdown
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A partial shutdown that began on December 22, 2018, and ended on January 25, 2019.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It was the longest government shutdown in nearly 50 years and set a benchmark for future shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: 35 days
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It marks the longest government shutdown in nearly five decades, highlighting the severity of funding lapses.

namedEntities.name: 800,000 federal employees
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Total number of people employed in shuttered federal agencies during the 2018 shutdown.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It illustrates the scale of workforce disruption during a shutdown, with 300,000 furloughed and 300,000 exempted.

namedEntities.name: 12 appropriations bills
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The required legislative bills needed to fund federal agencies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The failure to pass these bills results in a full government shutdown in 2025.

namedEntities.name: Furloughed employees
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal workers who were not paid and asked not to report to work during shutdowns.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are part of the workforce impacted during both the 2018 and current shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: Exempted employees
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal workers who were required to report to work but did not receive pay during shutdowns.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They were affected during the 2018 shutdown and are similarly affected in the current one.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major international news network reporting on the shutdown.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provides coverage and updates on the duration and impact of the shutdowns, including staff reporting on services affected.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article reports on the ongoing full government shutdown in the United States as of October 2025, resulting from Congress's failure to pass any of the 12 required appropriations bills. It contrasts this with the previous 35-day shutdown from December 2018 to January 2019—the longest in nearly 50 years—which cost the economy an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP and affected around 800,000 federal employees. The 2018 shutdown was partial, with some agencies operating under funding, while the current shutdown is full, affecting all federal operations. Political partisanship, a narrow Republican majority in the House under Speaker Mike Johnson, and the absence of 60 votes in the Senate to end a filibuster are key reasons negotiations have stalled. The article underscores the economic and operational costs of such shutdowns and highlights the ongoing struggle to pass critical funding legislation.
title: The last government shutdown was the longest in nearly 50 years. Here are all the recent shutdowns in one chart
